intro: Convolvulus hamrinensis, commonly known as the Hamrin bindweed, is a flowering plant native to the Middle East. It belongs to the Convolvulaceae family, which includes many species of flowering plants known for their climbing or trailing growth habits. The plant produces small, tubular flowers that are typically white or pale pink, often with five petals. It has heart-shaped leaves and a hairy stem, which are characteristic features of the genus Convolvulus. This species is often found in rocky or arid environments, showing its adaptability to harsh conditions.
